docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes when things slow down, the Bagger does his best thinking. Not that he is going to go all Mensa on you, but you know what they say about idle hands. Fer instance, a while back we did a story about the scrum over credits, and now that the ballots are shipping, it's worth revisiting. On one level, the fight over who gets credit for "Crash" is all of the worst of Hollywood - pettiness, ego, avarice - in one untidy multi-car pileup. On another, very real issues are at stake. On one side is the Producers Guild of Anerica and, by proxy, the Academy, seeking to control credit creep, in which everybody and his brother can say they produced a film. On the other, you have people like Bob Yari and Mark Harris, two of the guys who got stiffed in the new process of determining who gets actual credit come Oscar time, wondering who appointed these guys as arbiters of all that is good and holy in the production process. As indie productions grow and become a mainstay of the both the business and the aesthetic of the industry, movies are going to continue to come together in a complicated way. Mr. Yari has already sued one of his former production partners on "Crash," not just over the credit issue, but that certainly is one of the salient issues. Mr. Yari has made noises about actually going ahead and suing the Producers Guild, but that brings up a rather delicate issue. Mr. Yari continues to be financially staked in "Crash," and will benefit significantly if the movie ends up sneaking in as best picture. So, with that broader objective in mind, he and anybody else involved in "Crash" wants to get the Academy's attention. And suing the hand that feeds them, while it will accomplish that goal, will not endear the membership when "Crash" needs all the friends it can get.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mebbe it is just the Bagger, but do the ads for this year's Oscar contain a semiotic pitch for "Good Night, and Good Luck"? Look at the male version of the ad, which can be seen on billboards around L.A. right now. You have a suited male, face unseen, rendered in black and white. The only color in the picture comes from the golden guy himself. You don't have to squint your eyes too much to start thinking the classically attired male torso might be that of David Strathairn, George Clooney, or even Edward R. Murrow. Perhaps the Bagger's blood sugar is running a bit high and muddling his thinking, but now that he has put that little thought in your head, see if you ever look at the ad the same way again.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger is up late, having attended one of those dinner parties on the Upper West Side of Manhattan that he has come to dread. Hollywood has its rituals - the breakfast meeting being one of the more foul and unholy expressions of SoCal culture he finds inhumane - but in Manhattan, people frequently attend dinner parties out of a sense of duty, or fear that they will be left out the next time and actually get to do what they want instead. A frequent motif is dinner guests pretending to listen to each other but actually just rehearsing to come up with a sassy bit to top the person sitting to their left. But the Bagger's fears were misplaced. Dinner was lovely, the company was rocking, and he got a chance to talk a great deal about his favorite topic.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger stopped by the Bruce Wasserstein/Carl Icahn investor road show at the St. Regis yesterday. Mr. Wasserstein spent 30 minutes explaining why breaking Time Warner into a million little pieces - well, at least four - makes inescapable business sense. Not your great Oscar story, but pickings are slim this time of the season, and the Bagger will do what he can with what he's got. In this instance, if the pressure from Icahn were to force a de-merger, Warner Brothers, one of Hollywood's most reliable producers of tentpoles, would end up as its own darn thing, more or less. If things go that way, Warner might think about commissioning a movie called, "It Came from Another Part of the Boardroom," a thinly veiled biopic of Mr. Icahn, who managed to mangle Shakespeare and misidentify his would-be compatriot Mr. Wasserstein as "Ken." Mr. Wasserstein expressed significant admiration for News Corporation and Rupert Murdoch, but the gooey feeling is far from mutual. In an interview, Mr. Murdoch pointed out that Viacom Inc., another major media conglomerate, has so far achieved "little or nothing" for its shareholders in deciding to break up into two entities at the beginning of this year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday the Bagger exercised rare restraint in not linking to the nude picture of Scarlett Johansson and Keira Knightley. It was not just because he spilled his coffee when he opened up the New York Post and saw the Vanity Fair picture of the pair with some homeless guy who apparently wandered into the shoot. And it wasn't even that Ms. Johansson was selling crack, visually, in one of those magazine covers that will live in infamy. It's just that the Bagger did not want to participate in the objectification of two of the more promising young actors of our time - he's got three daughters to think about, after all. But last night he found a much more chaste link - Reuters via Yahoo - with a postage-size picture that renders its more naughty bits in miniature. Turns out Rachel McAdams decided not to go there at the last minute and bowed out, and that the issue includes George Clooney as well, although he kept his clothes on, perhaps because he didn't want to reveal some of the stretch marks he picked up by beefing up for his role in "Syriana."

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger has always had his speculations about Oscar's dating life. The golden guy does not set off the Bagger's gaydar in a huge way - unlike The Actor, which is given out by the Screen Actors Guild and is TOTALLY gay - but then there are some facts that are tough to get past. For example, what straight male do you know who would consider being clad head-to-toe in gold to be proper evening wear? And even though Oscar is 78 years old or so, he is incredibly buff, a tribute either to a moderate lifestyle or endless trips to the gym. Factor in the fact that Oscar spends his time adjacent to big stars, a constant familiar who is petted and stroked, and there are reasons to think that Oscar, if not an avowed homosexual, certainly has his moments, and may be more flexible than he appears to be.
